page.title: 03CLEVELAND - N YORK MOORS
page.content: Apart from a small area of coniferous woodland managed by the Forestry Commission on the slopes of the western escarpment, the area is typical heather clad moor at a height of 300-400 metres. There are no buildings in the area and people are rarely seen working: workers are shepherds, game-keepers and forestry workers. The area is crossed by two old routes, The Rudland Rigg road crosses it N/S and the abandoned Middlesborough/ Rosedale railway build 1870-1 crosses N/S and W/E. These routes are regularly used by walkers either for short local walks or as part of long distance walks e.g. The Lyke Wake, a 40 mile W/E crossing of the highest points of the North York Moors and three others; Rosedale Circiut; White Rose Challenge and Cleveland Way.
